instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 270mA
threads.message:
Board had little corrosion at <CAPACITOR>C7226</CAPACITOR> and cap fell off with a little push, check before removing cap and there was no short

Restoring T2 gives error about giving up waiting to transition from DFU to DFU

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> : 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> : 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> : 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> : 0.7V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> : 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 270mA
threads.message:
Pufff, corrosion sign at CPU power supply not good at all.
Check diode mode to ground on all MLB's coils and compare with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 270mA
threads.message:
Only <CAPACITOR>C7226</CAPACITOR> was affected by corrosion and was not shorted.
Diode measurements are fine, low resistance CPU lines were measured in ohms and were also fine.
Forgot to mention PPBUS is 12.2V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 270mA
threads.message: Check diode mode to ground on SSD power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 270mA
threads.message: All SSD power rails are on par with working board as far as diode measurements, they are of course missing voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 270mA
threads.message: Flash SoC ROM and try DFU again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 270mA
threads.message: I dont have a programmer for this ROM chip, I do have another one of this boards so I transplanted the ROM chip and did a restore and get the same error as before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 270mA
threads.message:
I expected to get a numeric code of that error.

Try DFU connecting a battery holding some charge.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 270mA
threads.message:
With a charged battery the Mac started up, this told me that one or more of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> was the problem, so I did more and more testing and found that one of the ports (The one used to restore) when plugging a USB Tester did not give me the 5V out, so I replaced it and boom! Mac working!

Thanks so much!
